['Falcon', 'Hawk', 'Eagle', 'Owl', 'Vulture', 'Harrier', 'Kite', 'Buzzard', 'Goshawk', 'Shrike', 'Detail every step of the process as it would occur in a real-world setting:', '**Preparation Phase**: The patient is prepped for the procedure, typically involving bowel preparation with laxatives or polyethylene glycol solution to clear the intestines', '**Informed Consent**: Obtain informed consent from the patient after explaining the risks, benefits, and alternatives of a colonoscopy procedure.', '**Patient Positioning**: Place the patient in the left lateral decubitus position with the right knee flexed towards the chest to provide optimal exposure and comfort during the examination.', '**Equipment Setup**: Assemble all necessary equipment, including a colonoscope, biopsy instruments, air/fluid injectors for insufflation, suction device, gloves, protective eyewear, lubricant jelly (Miralax or similar), and monitoring devices.', '**Anesthesia**: Administer conscious sedation to the patient using a combination of anxiolytics like midazolam, analgesics such as fentanyl, and oxygen through a face mask until the patient is comfortable but still awake.', '**Insertion**: Gently insert the colonoscope into the rectum and slowly advance it through the sigmoid colon while carefully monitoring for any signs of distress or discomfort in the patient.', '**Insufflation**: Inflate the colon with carbon dioxide to create a clear view of the mucosa, being careful not to overinflate and compromise blood flow (maximum pressure is generally around 150 mmHg).', '**Examination**: Examine the entire colon systematically for abnormalities such as polyps or lesions using the camera feed on a monitor attached to the scope', '**Withdrawal**: Gently withdraw the colonoscope once complete examination is concluded or when reaching the beginning of the sigmoid colon', '**Careful Withdrawal and Post-Procedure Care**: Remove all equipment, ensuring no foreign bodies are left in place, dispose of it according to biohazard protocols, and transfer the patient back to their bed for post-procedure recovery', "**Documentation**: Document all findings, procedures performed (including any biopsies), medications administered, equipment used, and patient's response to the procedure in their medical record."]
